author: By Tammy La Gorce
title: Two Dating Apps and 98 First Dates. Something Was Different About the 99th.
description: Inimai Chettiar showed the same determination in dating as she did with her work at the Justice Action Network. Kenneth Wolf Jr. helped bring romance back into her life.
content: In 2018, when Inimai Manickam Chettiar debated the author and television personality Van Jones on National Public Radio, issues plaguing her since childhood came roaring back. “It was one of my scariest professional moments,” she said. “Public speaking activates all my woman of color, I-don’t-belong-here insecurities.” The man who would help her face them, who happened to be a white Army veteran, is the same man she would soon fall in love with.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Bruni
title: Marco Rubio Deserves Ivanka Trump
description: Will the senator’s sycophancy and shape-shifting come to naught?
content: It’s a measure of the Republican Party’s current depravity that I think of the period when Marco Rubio was besmirching Donald Trump’s genitalia as the good old days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Sullivan
title: As Bitcoin’s Price Surges, Affluent Investors Start to Take a Look
description: Cryptocurrencies, originally a way to conduct business outside the financial system, are increasingly seen as an asset akin to private equity or venture capital.
content: Cryptocurrencies have soared in value. In a decade, they’ve gone from a fringe obsession that allowed coin holders to conduct business outside the financial system to an alternative investment managed as if it were any other investment. It hasn’t hurt that the price of a single Bitcoin has gone from zero to over $30,000 in that time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vincent M. Mallozzi
title: A Funny Thing Happened at the College Reunion
description: Alexis Branagan and Patrick Ryan caught eyes at a Princeton event. A first date quickly followed.
content: Alexis Branagan and Patrick Ryan arrived separately at the Cloister Inn eating club at Princeton in June 2017.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alix Wall
title: A Wedding With an Undeniable Force
description: When Bianca Hernandez met Frank Knight at a Star Wars event in 2016, they spoke briefly then she tracked him down on Facebook.
content: On a November evening in 2016, Bianca Hernandez attended Star Wars night at the California Academy of Sciences in San Francisco. In a room where costumed people dueled with lightsabers, she met Frank Knight, who was staffing a table while his friend took a bathroom break.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Grillo
title: From Feigning Intimacy to Falling in Love
description: On their first date at a small Rosh Hashana dinner, Dr. Margaret Soper and Jason Kessler made a split-second decision to act as though they were already a couple. It wasn’t long before they weren’t pretending.
content: It was a few days before Rosh Hashana, and Dr. Margaret Swenson Soper suddenly found herself with no plans. She had just learned that the tickets she thought she had to attend services had fallen through, and was feeling sorry for herself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Sharon Kay Penman, Whose Novels Plumbed Britain’s Past, Dies at 75
description: The author of best-selling books set in medieval England and Wales, she insisted that historical fiction had an obligation to the facts.
content: Sharon Kay Penman, a former tax lawyer whose best-selling epics about medieval England and Wales drew legions of admirers for her meticulous research and commitment to historical facts, died on Jan. 22 in a hospital in Atlantic City. She was 75.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Kelly, Erin Griffith, Andrew Ross Sorkin and Nathaniel Popper
title: Robinhood, in Need of Cash, Raises $1 Billion From Its Investors
description: The no-fee trading app, which is popular with young investors, has been strained by the high volume of trading this week in stocks such as GameStop.
content: Facing an onslaught of demands on its cash amid a stock market frenzy, Robinhood, the online trading app, said on Thursday that it was raising an infusion of more than $1 billion from its existing investors.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Vaccination Day at Dodger Stadium: Hours of Traffic and 7,730 Shots
description: Quotation of the Day for Friday, January 29, 2021.
content: “Thirty thousand cones. We had to get every cone that the city has, in every department — Water and Power, Transportation — and then buy more on top of that.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gonzalez
title: $20,000 for a Permit? New York May Finally Offer Vendors Some Relief
description: In an attempt to shut down a thriving black market, the City Council passed a bill that would increase the number of permits for street vendors.
content: Ahmed Ebrahim was born into the family business, selling hot dogs, knishes and pretzels from a cart near Rockefeller Center. He and his brother and business partner, Mahmoud, inherited the work ethic of their mother, Magda, who started as a street vendor more than 30 years ago after immigrating from Egypt. They also inherited a burden: paying $20,000 every two years for a vending permit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Dodge
title: If You’ve Ever Wanted to Be a Foster Parent, ‘Now Is the Time to Get Involved’
description: The process has changed during the pandemic, but getting started is easier than you might think.
content: Six years ago, Chastity and Mark Gomez, of Denver, were speaking with friends who had begun the process of becoming adoptive parents. After learning about the abuse and neglect suffered by so many children in the foster care system, many of whom need homes, they decided to get involved as well.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Old Rivals, New Ideas and Why Some Clubs Are Reluctant to Try
description: Rangers and Celtic are so focused on beating one another that they may have lost sight of the future. In Brazil, two rivals enter the Copa Libertadores final toying with a new concept: coaching stability.
content: Nobody wants to say it is over. Steven Gerrard, the Rangers manager, will not tempt fate. He will only believe the title is won, he has said, when the math says so. Neil Lennon, his counterpart at Celtic, similarly cannot concede defeat. His team, he has said, will keep going, keep fighting, while there is still some small glimmer of hope.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Egan
title: Kristin Hannah Reinvented Herself. She Thinks America Can Do the Same.
description: In “The Four Winds,” the author of “The Nightingale” and “The Great Alone” takes readers back to another era of environmental disaster, economic collapse and fresh starts.
content: Growing up in California and the Pacific Northwest, Kristin Hannah never wanted to become a novelist. It was a career for dreamers, she thought, kids who took creative writing classes and scribbled stories from the time they were 6.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Satariano
title: Inside a Pro-Huawei Influence Campaign
description: A covert online push to sway telecommunications policy in favor of the Chinese company may presage a new twist in social manipulation.
content: LONDON — Edwin Vermulst, a trade lawyer in Brussels, did not think twice before he agreed to write an article for Huawei, the Chinese telecommunications giant, that would criticize a Belgian policy that threatened to box the company out of lucrative contracts. He had worked with the company for years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Will Wright
title: A Washington hospital system apologizes after offering vaccines to wealthy donors.
description: A Washington hospital system apologized after The Seattle Times reported that it had offered vaccines to wealthy donors while others went without the coveted shots.
content: A Washington hospital system apologized after The Seattle Times reported that it had offered vaccines to wealthy donors while others went without the coveted shots.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: Should Schools Be Able to Discipline Students for What They Say on Social Media?
description: The case of a high school cheerleader who was suspended from her team for comments she made on social media may be heading to the Supreme Court. Do schools have the right to censor or punish students for speech outside of their grounds?
content: A student makes an offensive joke on Instagram.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah Engel Bromwich
title: N.Y.P.D. Officer Solicited Sexual Photos From 46 Minors, U.S. Says
description: Federal prosecutors said Officer Carmine Simpson posed as a 17-year-old online and coaxed dozens of teenagers to send him sexual videos and photos.
content: A New York City police officer was arrested on child pornography charges on Thursday after he repeatedly posed as a teenager online to request and obtain sexually explicit photos and videos from at least 46 minors, federal prosecutors said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marie Tae McDermott
title: The Debate Over Reopening California Schools
description: Friday: Education leaders and teachers have openly criticized the state’s reopening plan. Parents and legislators are not backing down.
content: Good morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Denise Grady
title: Which Covid Vaccine Should You Get? Experts Cite the Effect Against Severe Disease
description: Infectious disease doctors say getting a shot of the J&J vaccine, which has a lower efficacy against the virus than other vaccines, would still be well worthwhile.
content: At first glance, the results reported on Friday from the long-awaited trial of Johnson & Johnson’s coronavirus vaccine might have seemed disappointing. Its overall efficacy — the ability to prevent moderate and severe disease — was reported at 72 percent in the United States, 66 percent in Latin American countries and 57 percent in South Africa.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy La Gorce
title: Jinkx Monsoon Goes ‘Low-Key’ on Wedding Day
description: The “RuPaul’s Drag Race” winner marries an Englishman, Michael Abbott, in their living room. Mr. Abbott is back in Manchester, England for now.
content: If Jerick Hoffer had gotten married 10 years ago instead of Jan. 9, the ceremony would have been drag queen fabulous. “I still had a yen for causing a spectacle then,” said Mx. Hoffer, who goes by the stage name Jinkx Monsoon and  uses they/them pronouns. “Nowadays, I’m much more low-key.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hailey Fuchs
title: Capitol Police Call for More Security, Prompting Debate Over How Far to Go
description: The Capitol Police, Washington’s mayor and lawmakers are weighing options for permanent fencing around Congress and bigger forces to respond to continuing threats.
content: WASHINGTON — The acting chief of the Capitol Police called on Thursday for “vast improvements” to security on the Capitol grounds, including permanent fencing and “the availability of ready, backup forces,” setting off a debate over how far to go in hardening the iconic location against continuing threats.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: I’m Not Actually Interested in Mitch McConnell’s Hypocrisy
description: To make his case for the filibuster, he has essentially rewritten the history of the Senate.
content: On Tuesday, Mitch McConnell, now the Senate minority leader, spoke in defense of the legislative filibuster.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: There’s Nothing Better Than This Cheesy Potato Soup
description: Silky-smooth and simple to make, it gets verve and heat from homemade pickled jalapeños.
content: One of the many upsides to having a spouse who loves to bake bread is that our soup consumption goes up as the temperatures go down. Because, really, is there a homier winter meal than a butter-slathered slice of sourdough dunked in a bowl of homemade soup?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Victor
title: A Pandemic Is Hard Enough. For Some, Being Single Has Made It Harder.
description: “One day I realized it had been three months since I had touched a human being,” one man said.
content: The coronavirus pandemic has been rough on virtually everyone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: Biden Moves Cautiously on Health Care
description: “There’s nothing new that we’re doing here”: This is your morning tip sheet.
content: Biden starts turning back Trump’s attacks on Obamacare, and General Motors makes a big commitment. It’s Friday, and this is your politics tip sheet. Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Grillo
title: An Instant Connection, Cemented by a Sweet Gift
description: After their first date, Kara Cheever and Fuery Hocking felt like they had known each other for years. After their second, Mr. Hocking made sure to send Ms. Cheever her favorite dessert for her birthday.
content: On a Sunday night in early September 2017, Kara Eileen Cheever called her sister. She had just gotten home from her first date with Fuery Thomas Hocking, after matching with him on the dating app Bumble. What was supposed to be a casual afternoon walk in Central Park with Ms. Cheever’s dog, Percy, had lasted into evening.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Imani Perry
title: Do We Ask Too Much of Black Heroes?
description: Every year for a month, we celebrate the heroes of Black history. But these stories can obscure how change happens and who gets left behind.
content: This is the first piece in “Black History, Continued,” a series that will explore pivotal moments and transformative figures in Black culture and examine how the past shapes the present and the future.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater and Matthew Rosenberg
title: Republican Ties to Extremist Groups Are Under Scrutiny
description: A number of members of Congress have links to organizations and movements that played a role in the Jan. 6 assault on the Capitol.
content: WASHINGTON — The video’s title was posed as a question, but it left little doubt about where the men who filmed it stood. They called it “The Coming Civil War?” and in its opening seconds, Jim Arroyo, who leads an Arizona chapter of Oath Keepers, a right-wing militia, declared that the conflict had already begun.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler and Benjamin Mueller
title: Vaccine Rollout Gives U.K. a Rare Win in Battling Pandemic
description: “Vaccination is the one thing we’ve gotten right.” How a country that botched so much of its pandemic response has managed one of the fastest rollouts in the world.
content: LONDON — When the pizza-sized boxes of the Pfizer vaccine arrived midday Thursday, an hour behind schedule, it set off a race against the clock at the Bloomsbury Surgery, a medical clinic in London’s Camden district that has been transformed during the pandemic into a humming vaccination center.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Traub
title: What Should Drive Biden’s Foreign Policy?
description: The fiery Cold War liberalism of Hubert Humphrey provides a guide on how to act, abroad and at home.
content: In May 1950, Hubert Humphrey, the firebrand liberal from Minnesota, took to the floor of the Senate to call for passage of a fair employment practices commission to root out systematic racial discrimination in hiring. “So long as men and women and children of color are discriminated against in the United States,” Senator Humphrey insisted, “the colored people of the world have the right to suspect our professed friendship for them.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Finn and Richard Malley
title: One Dose Now for Everyone Most Likely to Die
description: Forget boosters and more trials. America’s overly prudent vaccination strategy is killing people.
content: In the race to prevent ever more deaths from Covid-19, the United States faces two major problems: not having enough doses of vaccine on hand and struggling to deliver those that are available. According to data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, as of Jan. 28 about 48.4 million doses had been distributed, but only 26.2 million administered.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons
title: How Mayor de Blasio Plans to Lead the City Out of the Pandemic
description: The mayor announced an ambitious plan to help New York City recover, including vaccinating five million residents by June.
content: In his final State of the City address, Mayor Bill de Blasio offered a sprawling vision of New York City’s recovery from a pandemic that has taken tens of thousands of lives and destroyed the city’s economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erik DeLapp
title: Feeling Lonely? Wearing Cat Ears May Help
description: There may be no better time than the present to find love on multiplayer online role-playing games.
content: The first time I met Jessica in person was when she walked out of the sliding doors of the Minneapolis-St. Paul International Airport wearing a flowing skirt, beaded necklaces and a paper bag over her head.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sydney Franklin
title: Hamptons Real Estate Hits Record Levels in the Pandemic
description: The median sale price rose by 40 percent in 2020, while the volume of sales increased 37 percent.
content: As New York City’s real estate market foundered during the pandemic in 2020, home sales in the Hamptons boomed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tina Jordan
title: The Very First Cover of the Book Review
description: Celebrating a 125th anniversary by returning to the beginning of a supplement designed as “an open forum for the discussion of books.”
content: This year, the Book Review turns 125.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Cohen
title: Macron Tells Biden That Cooperation With U.S. Cannot Be Dependence
description: In a “very agreeable call,” the French president told his American counterpart that Europe wanted “strategic autonomy.” In an interview with foreign media, he also reflected on the pandemic and threats to democracy.
content: PARIS — President Emmanuel Macron of France said in an interview Friday that for Europe to be a credible partner to the United States it also had to be “an autonomous partner” with its own military and technological capacities, because “cooperation cannot be dependence.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Why Robinhood Had to Risk Infuriating Its Customers
description: The online broker raised $1 billion to prop itself up. Overcoming customer anger may be harder.
content: Robinhood had to raise $1 billion from investors yesterday to help it cover cash demands during the week’s trading frenzy, while traders and lawmakers sharply criticized the online broker for halting some trading in Reddit-touted stocks. In short: The consequences of the mania in GameStop, AMC and other stocks are becoming more concrete — and, in Robinhood’s case, more serious.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalia Winkelman
title: ‘Palmer’ Review: A Crisis of Masculinity
description: Justin Timberlake stars as an ex-convict who interrogates his gender biases after he comes to care for a young boy in this prosaic melodrama.
content: Like a bad egg set to boil, a rugged ex-convict softens and then cracks in the pallid drama “Palmer.” The film, streaming on Apple TV+, opens with its stoic protagonist returning home to rural Louisiana after serving a 12-year prison sentence. Palmer (Justin Timberlake) hits the bar and carouses with buddies, but his townie itinerary changes when he finds himself saddled with caring for Sam (Ryder Allen), the cherubic child of a neglectful neighbor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier and Claire Moses
title: A Victory for Farmers in a David-and-Goliath Environmental Case
description: An appeals court said a small group of farmers in the Niger Delta region whose livelihoods were affected by oil spills in 2006 and 2007 should receive payouts.
content: A Dutch court ruled on Friday that a subsidiary of the British-Dutch multinational Royal Dutch Shell was liable for oil spills in the Niger Delta in Nigeria in 2006 and 2007, ordering the company to compensate a small group of residents in the region and to start purifying contaminated waters within weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Goldstein
title: John Chaney, Hall of Fame Temple Basketball Coach, Dies at 89
description: He won more than 500 games and six Atlantic 10 tournament championships with Temple, and he took his teams to the N.C.A.A. tournament’s regional finals five times.
content: John Chaney, the famously combative Hall of Fame coach who took Temple University to 17 N.C.A.A. basketball tournaments, largely recruiting high school players from poor neighborhoods who were overlooked by the college game’s national powers, died on Friday. He was 89.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser and Concepción de León
title: ‘It’s Numbing’: Nine Retired Nuns in Michigan Die of Covid-19
description: The deaths add to what is becoming a familiar trend in the spread of the virus as it devastates religious congregate communities by infecting retired, aging populations of nuns and sisters.
content: The religious sisters who lived in retired seclusion at the Dominican Life Center in Michigan followed strict rules to avoid an outbreak of coronavirus infection: They were kept in isolation, visitors were prohibited and masks were required by everyone on campus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Veronique Greenwood
title: How an Eight-Sided ‘Egg’ Ended Up in a Robin’s Nest
description: An experiment by evolutionary biologists offers new insights into birds’ brains.
content: Last spring, robins living on an Illinois tree farm sat on some unusual eggs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Audra D. S. Burch and John Eligon
title: Prosecutor Wants Rayshard Brooks Case Moved, Blaming Her Predecessor
description: Pointing to the conduct of the district attorney she defeated last year, Fani Willis concluded her office should not pursue the case against a former Atlanta officer who killed Mr. Brooks.
content: Fani Willis was still a candidate for district attorney of Georgia’s largest county when she concluded that the office should not handle the high-profile case against a former Atlanta police officer charged in the fatal shooting of Rayshard Brooks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: Billionaires Bicker Over Space Toys
description: They should instead focus on the big question: Can satellites bring internet access to billions?
content: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nellie Bowles
title: Join Us in Miami! Love, Masters of the Universe
description: Silicon Valley techies and Wall Street titans have bought homes and moved businesses there in the pandemic, coaxed by an eager mayor.
content: MIAMI — America’s business leaders, freed from the office, looked around the country, taking note of its coronavirus lockdowns, taxes and rabble rousers. And many said as if in unison: Miami!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: Job Seekers With Trump White House on Their Résumés Face a Cold Reality
description: Working at the White House has traditionally been a ticket to a lucrative future. But that hasn’t been the case so far for Trump alumni.
content: WASHINGTON — After announcing her departure from the Trump administration in the middle of the Jan. 6 assault on the Capitol, Sarah Matthews, a deputy White House press secretary, kept running into the same question as she worked her contacts to find a new job: What was it like?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eliza Shapiro
title: New York Schools Are Segregated. Will the Next Mayor Change That?
description: By deferring decisions on desegregating schools, Mayor Bill de Blasio has pushed those choices onto his successor — and into the race to replace him.
content: During a recent forum on education, a moderator asked the crowded field of Democrats running to be New York City’s next mayor a question they may not have wanted to answer: How would they approach the fraught issue of admissions into the city’s selective schools, where Black and Latino students are starkly underrepresented?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: In Biden’s White House, Masks, Closed Doors and Empty Halls
description: The West Wing has become a different place in an administration serious about Covid restrictions.
content: WASHINGTON — Senior staff members limit interactions with each other in most offices to a total of 15 minutes in a day. No more than six people are allowed to gather in the Oval Office at a time, and a maximum of five staff members are allowed to meet together in the spacious office of the chief of staff, Ron Klain. In the Roosevelt Room, where staff meet every afternoon for a planning meeting on the coronavirus rescue plan, gatherings are limited to 10 people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise
title: ‘Trump Just Used Us and Our Fear’: One Woman’s Journey Out of QAnon
description: During the political fallout after four years of Donald J. Trump, one question is what will happen with the followers of conspiracy theories that bend Americans’ perceptions of reality.
content: To hear more audio stories from publishers like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Friday Briefing
description: Mixed results from Novavax’s vaccine trials.
content: The pharmaceutical company Novavax said for the first time yesterday that its Covid-19 vaccine offered robust protection against the coronavirus: An early analysis of a 15,000-person trial in Britain revealed that the two-dose vaccine had an efficacy rate of nearly 90 percent there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Convictions
description: Robyn Weintraub starts our weekend off with authority.
content: FRIDAY PUZZLE — Solvers, how can we not believe in ESP? Every time I see Robyn Weintraub’s name on a grid, I know I’m going to love it. Today’s puzzle separates nicely into quarters, each hanging on a pair of 10-letter entries that make for all kinds of fun word association.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Arraf and Falih Hassan
title: U.S. Airstrike Kills Top ISIS Leader in Iraq
description: The joint operation with Iraqi forces was aimed at stemming the group’s resurgence, and illustrates Iraq’s continued reliance on the U.S. military.
content: BAGHDAD — American airstrikes in a joint mission with Iraqi forces have killed the top Islamic State leader in Iraq, an attack aimed at stemming the group’s resurgence and exacting retribution for a deadly double-suicide bombing in Baghdad last week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Corky Lee, Who Photographed Asian-American Life, Dies at 73
description: Mr. Lee was determined to correct history that left out Asian-Americans, and to document their present-day lives and struggles. He died of Covid-19.
content: Corky Lee, a photographer who was determined both to restore the contributions of Asian-Americans to the historical record and to document their present-day lives and struggles, especially those living in New York, died on Wednesday in Queens. He was 73.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nathaniel Popper and Kellen Browning
title: The ‘Roaring Kitty’ Rally: How a Reddit User and His Friends Roiled the Markets
description: A Massachusetts man who goes by “Roaring Kitty” on social media helped fuel the frenzy around GameStop. His $53,000 investment in the company briefly reached $48 million in value.
content: In mid-2019, a Reddit user — known as “Roaring Kitty” on some social media accounts — posted a picture on an online forum depicting a single $53,000 investment in the video-game retailer GameStop.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Grape-Nuts, Supermarket Mainstay, Is No Longer So Easy to Find
description: A supply shortage of the venerable, if polarizing, cereal has customers scouring online for boxes, sometimes listed at inflated prices.
content: Grape-Nuts cereal, the supermarket mainstay that is made of neither grapes nor nuts, beloved by some and hated by others, has become hard to find.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning
title: Still Looking for a New Gaming Console? Here’s Why
description: A month after the holiday season, gamers are still contending with scalpers, bots and immense demand as they hunt for elusive devices.
content: One Saturday in mid-December, Chris Vernon was driving as fast as he could to a GameStop in Memphis. He had spent weeks combing the internet for new PlayStation 5 consoles, and had just heard about a new shipment’s arrival at a store nearby. It was the only present his 10-year-old son, William, wanted for Christmas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vincent M. Mallozzi
title: A Librarian and a Listener Wed
description: Rory Jelinski was a strong presence for Portia Carryer when her beloved German shepherd died.
content: In fall 2019, Portia Carryer was mourning the loss of her beloved dog, a German shepherd named Rilke. That’s when Rory Jelinski made her presence felt.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Weinstein
title: These Recipes Are So Smart
description: Cook with a few sharp shortcuts, clever techniques and ingredients in new contexts.
content: Hello and welcome to Five Weeknight Dishes, a newsletter for busy people who still want something good to eat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nossiter and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
title: Violence May Delay U.S. Troop Withdrawal From Afghanistan
description: The Biden administration is reviewing a deal between its predecessor and the Taliban for a May 1 deadline to pull all American troops out of the country.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — Both the Afghan government and its Taliban foes appear to be gearing up for a violent spring amid uncertainty over whether the Biden administration will meet a May 1 deadline for the withdrawal of all American troops from Afghanistan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher
title: G.M.’s Electric Car Push Could Put China in the Driver’s Seat
description: With government support and lavish subsidies, Chinese companies have come to dominate the market for batteries, motors and other essentials Detroit may need for its new fleets.
content: SHANGHAI — The business of making cars has reached a critical juncture — and it looks as if China is in the driver’s seat.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Conspiracy Theory Is Proved Wrong
description: The inauguration of Joe Biden shattered the fundamentals of the baseless QAnon theory. What happens to its followers now?
content: This episode contains strong language.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ginny Hogan
title: Order and Chaos, Mostly Chaos, in 3 Debut Novels
description: New fiction starring a 7-year-old selling hardware, a disgraced queer playwright, and an unlikely throuple expecting a child.
content: HOW TO ORDER THE UNIVERSEBy María José Ferrada Translated by Elizabeth Bryer 180 pp. Tin House. $19.95.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Kurczy
title: Isidore Torres, Trailblazing Hispanic Judge in Michigan, Dies at 73
description: A child of migrant workers, he served more than 25 years in the Wayne County court system and advocated for other Latinos in the legal profession. He died of Covid-19.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Philipps
title: Pentagon Begins Independent Inquiry Into Special Ops and War Crimes
description: The Defense Department inspector general will examine whether elite U.S. commando forces are doing enough to comply with the laws of armed conflict and hold violators accountable.
content: For decades the Defense Department has relied on covert and classified special operations troops to kick in doors and raid high-value targets around the world. The department’s Inspector General’s Office now may be taking its first broad look at whether those shadowy strike forces committed war crimes along the way.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Susan Orlean Lists Her Upstate Retreat
description: The writer’s modern three-bedroom house, lined with wood and stone, comes with a $3.495 million price tag.
content: Birds’ nests may not be all that unusual in the Hudson Valley. But at the rural retreat of Susan Orlean, the author and writer for The New Yorker known for her animals beat, the most notable tangles of sticks and straw are not in trees but her kitchen, displayed along a neat bluestone wall just to the left of her refrigerator.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Evan Hill and Arielle Ray
title: Body Camera Footage Shows Capitol Rioters Trampling Over Woman
description: Video obtained by The Times provides a police officer’s view of the deadly battle to defend a key entryway from the surging mob.
content: As 34-year-old Rosanne Boyland lay dying on the steps of the Capitol on Jan. 6 after being crushed by a mob, fellow rioters were charging over her to attack police officers with crutches, a hockey stick and pepper spray, new police body camera footage shows.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Biden’s Health Care Moves
description: And what else you need to know today.
content: Obamacare endured a grueling first decade of existence. Its launch was famously clunky. It was unpopular in its early years. It narrowly escaped repeal at both the Supreme Court and in Congress.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles, Jon Caramanica and Giovanni Russonello
title: Kodak Black Celebrates Clemency From Trump, and 10 More New Songs
description: Hear tracks by FKA twigs, Jupiter & Okwess, Prettymuch and others.
content: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shoshana Zuboff
title: The Coup We Are Not Talking About
description: We can have democracy, or we can have a surveillance society, but we cannot have both.
content: Two decades ago, the American government left democracy’s front door open to California’s fledgling internet companies, a cozy fire lit in welcome. In the years that followed, a surveillance society flourished in those rooms, a social vision born in the distinct but reciprocal needs of public intelligence agencies and private internet companies, both spellbound by a dream of total information awareness. Twenty years later, the fire has jumped the screen, and on Jan. 6, it threatened to burn down democracy’s house.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amal El-Mohtar
title: Mystery Boxes and Budding Loves: New Science Fiction and Fantasy
description: “The Absolute Book,” by Elizabeth Knox, takes on a number of genres, while “Winter’s Orbit,” by Everina Maxwell, stays true to one.
content: Here are two novels that are, in some ways, opposites: one by an author who’s been publishing celebrated work for 40 years, and one a debut; one that blends numerous genres with a skillful and inquiring hand, and one that glories in modeling a single genre by hitting every one of its notes. Between them they contrast the pleasures of surprise with those of satisfied expectations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gelles
title: Elon Musk Becomes Unlikely Anti-Establishment Hero in GameStop Saga
description: The billionaire has inserted himself into the confounding stock market drama and solidified his role as the ultimate insider outsider.
content: Just weeks before Elon Musk became the richest person in the world thanks to the soaring value of Tesla shares, the eccentric billionaire reflected on the fickle nature of the public markets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charanna Alexander
title: Love Letter: Falling in Love While Playing Games
description: And: You’re invited, now get vaccinated.
content: Gone are the days when cultivating a romantic relationship with someone you met online was considered taboo. However, for gaming enthusiasts who find love while battling exotic creatures in a parallel universe, explaining how you met might raise eyebrows.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ann Carrns
title: Changes in FAFSA May Reduce College Aid for Some Families
description: A new formula will no longer offer a break to many parents who have multiple children in college at the same time, experts say.
content: A new, shorter version of the federal student aid form is aimed at encouraging more families to complete it and qualify for financial help. But tweaks to its underlying formula could reduce aid for some families, particularly more affluent ones with more than one child in college.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liz Alderman and Jack Ewing
title: France and Germany slowly emerge from severe recessions.
description: Severe recessions in Germany and France last year, caused by the coronavirus pandemic, began to improve slightly toward the end of 2020, as a second series of lockdowns had a milder impact on their economies, those governments reported on Friday.
content: Severe recessions in Germany and France last year, caused by the coronavirus pandemic, began to improve slightly toward the end of 2020, as a second series of lockdowns had a milder impact on their economies, those governments reported on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: The W.H.O. drops opposition to vaccinations for pregnant women.
description: The change aligns the organization with the guidance from the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.
content: The World Health Organization on Friday changed its guidance for pregnant women considering a Covid-19 vaccine, abandoning opposition to immunization for most expectant mothers unless they were at high risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kravitz Hoeffner
title: 5 Restaurants on Why They’re Hibernating This Winter
description: Whether it’s because of generous landlords, loans or sheer exhaustion, owners are taking a seasonal break.
content: As the pandemic drags on this winter, much of the city that never sleeps is taking an extended snooze. This is especially true for restaurants, several of which are going into hibernation mode instead of braving the financially risky and uncomfortable conditions of outdoor service. Although Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s recent decision to bring back indoor service at 25 percent capacity on Feb. 14 gives the restaurant scene a glimmer of hope, some owners remain unsure about exactly how or when they will reopen. So for now, they hibernate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tom Mashberg
title: Museum of the Bible Returns Artifacts to Egypt
description: Egypt had asserted that the items were ferreted out amid the Arab Spring. The antiquities are among those at the museum lacking proper paperwork.
content: The Museum of the Bible in Washington, which has been bedeviled since its inception in 2017 by claims that it acquired thousands of biblical artifacts on the black market, has quietly repatriated 5,000 manuscripts and bits of papyrus to Egypt, which has long asserted the items were ferreted from the country in 2011 amid the upheavals of the Arab Spring.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert D. McFadden
title: Cicely Tyson, an Actress Who Shattered Stereotypes, Dies at 96
description: In a remarkable career of many decades, she refused to take parts that demeaned Black people and won a Tony, Emmys and an honorary Oscar.
content: Cicely Tyson, the stage, screen and television actress whose vivid portrayals of strong African-American women shattered racial stereotypes in the dramatic arts of the 1970s, propelling her to stardom and fame as an exemplar for civil rights, died on Thursday.  She was 96.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: The Joy of Watching Other People Clean
description: In this corner of YouTube, you can watch someone else clean the house — and you won’t be alone.
content: Tune into Jessica Tull’s YouTube channel, with its half a million subscribers, and you can watch her clean her house. Really.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Tracy
title: New York Times Reporter Used Racial Slur With Student Group
description: Remarks in 2019 by Donald G. McNeil Jr., a science correspondent, during an educational trip led to complaints from students and parents. The Times offered an apology.
content: A New York Times science and health correspondent whose reporting on the coronavirus pandemic has been a regular part of the newspaper’s front page and its leading podcast, “The Daily,” used a racial slur while serving as an expert guide on a Times-sponsored trip for high school students, The Times said on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liam Stack
title: Cardinal Dolan, the leader of New York’s Catholic Church, is in quarantine.
description: Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan, the leader of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, was in quarantine on Friday after he interacted last week with a person who later tested positive for the coronavirus, according to a spokesman.
content: Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan, the leader of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, was in quarantine on Friday after he interacted last week with a person who later tested positive for the coronavirus, according to a spokesman.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ezra Klein
title: What’s Happening to Our Economy Is Like a Natural Disaster
description: Ezra Klein and Paul Krugman discuss Covid economics, cryptocurrencies and deficit delusions.
content: The Biden administration’s first legislative priority is a $1.9 trillion economic rescue package. It’s the kind of mega-package where the individual policies contained inside it — a $15 minimum wage, $1,400 checks, a huge child tax credit expansion, a $50 billion virus testing infrastructure — would be big deals on their own. But together, this would be one of the most consequential packages ever passed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Weekend
description: Embrace projects, like fresh pasta dough, a mushroom lasagna, or Spicy Big Tray Chicken.
content: Good morning. We’re deep in winter on the East Coast of the United States, starting and finishing our days in darkness, frost on the windowpanes, salty grit at the doorstep. It’d be nice to have a roaring fire this weekend, at some giant pile of a house like something out a John Irving novel, sit on a couch in front of it for a while, then head into the huge kitchen to make dinner: a fresh ham; baked beans; mashed parsnips; a honking big double apple pie.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: How Many Americans Are Homeless? No One Knows
description: But more cities are carefully tracking these populations — and making progress in addressing the problem.
content: Many Americans imagine that the homeless are mostly people who made bad choices. They imagine the homeless are mostly single men. They imagine the government is trying to end homelessness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joanne B. Freeman
title: Why 1850 Doesn’t Feel So Far Away
description: Congress has been here before. It wasn’t pretty.
content: Scarcely had the violence ebbed on Capitol Hill on Jan. 6 when the Republican calls for healing began. Representative Debbie Lesko of Arizona made an anti-impeachment cease-and-desist plea on Jan. 12 that was typical of many. Addressing Democrats, she warned that impeachment would “further divide our country, further the unrest and possibly incite more violence.” Senator Lindsey Graham of South Carolina concurred, declaring on Fox News that calls for impeachment would “incite more violence” and “divide the country.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: ‘Gomorrah’ Is Back, as Bloody (and Gripping) as Ever
description: The crime series is so popular in its native Italy that it has filtered into language and culture. Some critics decry its portrayal of Naples, while others praise its realism and universal themes.
content: ROME — A few minutes into the third season of “Gomorrah,” the highly popular Italian television series about organized crime in Naples, which began streaming on HBO Max this month, the show’s brooding protagonist muses on the recent death of his father.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Seth Berkman
title: Professional Hockey Is Disrupted by Coronavirus
description: The N.H.L. had its ninth postponement of the season on Thursday, and one of the six teams in the National Women’s Hockey League had to leave its two-week season early.
content: Like the N.F.L., the N.B.A. and college sports, professional hockey has run into a slew of postponements, undermanned rosters and cancellations as leagues pushed ahead with plans to start their seasons this month during the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeff Sommer
title: How to Keep Your Cool in the GameStop Market
description: Signs of irrational exuberance abound. Stay sober and invest for the long run, our columnist says.
content: Even during a calm stretch on Wall Street, the stock market contains pockets of madness. But these days have been anything but calm. One word captures it: GameStop.
source.name: The New York Times

title: What Do Lars Ulrich and A.O. Scott Have in Common? A Lot, It Turns Out
description: The Metallica musician and our film critic have both spent their careers thinking about the creative process and how it’s received. They compared notes.
content: In December, Rolling Stone asked Lars Ulrich, the Metallica drummer, which celebrity he’d most want to quarantine with. His surprising answer was The New York Times’s co-chief film critic A.O. Scott. We knew they had to meet, and on Tuesday they chatted via video for more than 90 minutes about the creative process, criticism and what happens when their children disagree with their artistic tastes. Ulrich even stumped our critic when it came to movies. Here are edited excerpts from the conversation
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coralie Kraft
title: Comfort Viewing: 3 Reasons I Love ‘Firefly’
description: An Emmy-winning space western that was canceled after one season, the series is a perfect mix of palliative and palate cleanser.
content: If, as a young teen, you experienced a fiery sexual awakening the first time you set eyes on Harrison Ford’s fitted pants in “Star Wars,” you should make Joss Whedon’s “Firefly” your next pandemic binge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: Tonys Voting is Coming Soon. The Awards? We Still Don’t Know.
description: Organizers of the ceremony have firmed up dates for selecting favorites, but won’t commit to an event until plans for Broadway’s return are set.
content: The question has preoccupied Broadway lovers for months: When are the Tony Awards?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: ‘Bridgerton’ Has Nothing on the Couture
description: Men at Valentino and Fendi. Movies at Dior. A horse at Chanel. Thank goodness for the disruption amid the very fancy clothes.
content: The death of the haute couture — those wildly expensive, wildly extravagant clothes, made by hand for the very, very few — has been often predicted. It was predicted during the Great Recession, for obvious reasons. It was predicted during the rise of streetwear, thanks to social evolution. It was predicted as more and more fashion houses began to drop off the couture schedule, including Balmain and Saint Laurent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Herrman
title: Everything’s a Joke Until It’s Not
description: Reddit communities grow powerful in plain sight. Why do they keep taking the world by surprise?
content: Read this in the little voice in your head, and tell me it doesn’t sound familiar: Is this for real? It’s got to run out of steam. It can’t just keep going like this. How is this even happening?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Former Boy Scouts Chaplain Is Sentenced to 40 Years in Prison for Sexual Abuse
description: James Glawson, 76, sexually assaulted six young men, including one who is developmentally disabled, Rhode Island authorities said.
content: A former chaplain for the Boy Scouts in Rhode Island was sentenced on Thursday to 40 years in prison after pleading no contest to charges that he sexually assaulted six young men, the authorities said — the latest reckoning for a national scouting movement beleaguered by sex-abuse claims.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: Former U.S. Climate Leaders Press Biden on Amazon Deforestation
description: Former environmental officials from both parties are pressing President Biden to counter deforestation in the Amazon, especially in Brazil.
content: WASHINGTON — During his presidential campaign, Joseph R. Biden Jr. said the United States should mobilize $20 billion to stop the destruction of the Amazon rainforest and impose “significant economic consequences” if deforestation continued.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lucy Tompkins and Giulia McDonnell Nieto del Rio
title: A ‘bunch of kids’ ran a major vaccination site for Philadelphia. Then the city cut its ties.
description: With pressure mounting to get Covid-19 vaccine doses into arms as quickly as possible, many overburdened city health departments across the country have turned to partnerships with hospitals, nonprofit organizations and pharmacies. In Philadelphia this week, one such deal went awry after the city leaned on a start-up led by college students who were eager to get involved but had little experience.

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: My Attempt to Prepare for a Future Without Google
description: After the tech giant threatened to take its search engine offline in Australia, I’ve been looking into some alternatives.
content: It’s the first port of call for any random question that pops into our heads. The repository of basically all knowledge on the internet. The search engine so ubiquitous it’s a verb.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor, Jenny Gross and Michael Levenson
title: 11 Fort Bliss Soldiers Hospitalized After Drinking Antifreeze, Officials Say
description: Two of those taken ill were in an intensive care unit, military officials said, adding that the soldiers had believed they were consuming alcohol.
content: Eleven soldiers at Fort Bliss in Texas remained hospitalized on Friday, one day after they drank antifreeze, believing it was alcohol, during a field training exercise, military officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Krauss
title: New in Paperback: ‘Supreme Inequality’ and ‘Little Gods’
description: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
content: YOUNG HEROES OF THE SOVIET UNION: A Memoir and a Reckoning, by Alex Halberstadt. (Random House, 320 pp., $18.) Titled after his first-grade history textbook, Halberstadt’s “lush and moving” account of his family and the country where he was born, the Times book critic Jennifer Szalai noted, is also “skeptical, surprising and often very funny.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: He’s Israel’s ‘prince of Torah.’ But to some, he’s the king of Covid.
description: Rabbi Chaim Kanievsky, 93, can’t use a phone. He rarely leaves his house. His family says he has never successfully made a cup of tea. His closest aides think he doesn’t know the name of Israel’s prime minister. He studies the Torah for, give or take, 17 hours a day.

source.name: The New York Times

title: The First Post-Reagan Presidency
description: So far, Joe Biden has been surprisingly progressive.
content: During Donald Trump’s presidency, I sometimes took comfort in the Yale political scientist Stephen Skowronek’s concept of “political time.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette and Coral Davenport
title: G.M. Announcement Shakes Up U.S. Automakers’ Transition to Electric Cars
description: Every carmaker is trying to figure out how to make the leap before governments force it and Tesla and other start-ups lure away drivers.
content: A new president took office this month determined to fight climate change. Wall Street investors think Tesla is worth more than General Motors, Toyota, Volkswagen and Ford put together. And China, the world’s biggest car market, recently ordered that most new cars be powered by electricity in just 15 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: Hailed as a Trailblazer, Kim Ng Stands Alone
description: Major League Baseball celebrated the hiring of a woman as a sign of progress on diversity in its executive ranks. Every comparable hire over the last two years has been a white man.
content: Kim Ng brought hope to baseball when the Miami Marlins hired her as the team’s general manager in November, making her the first woman and second person of Asian descent to run a major-league team’s baseball operations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: Ex-F.B.I. Lawyer Who Altered Email in Russia Case Is Sentenced to Probation
description: A judge rebuffed a request by prosecutors to impose a prison sentence on Kevin Clinesmith, who admitted doctoring an email used to help authorize a wiretap on a former Trump campaign aide.
content: A former F.B.I. lawyer who has admitted doctoring an email during preparations to seek renewed court permission to wiretap a former Trump campaign aide during the Russia investigation was sentenced on Friday to one year of probation and 400 hours of community service — but no prison time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kaya Laterman
title: How a Kabbalistic Tarot Card Reader Spends His Sundays
description: He was introduced to the spiritual practice while traveling to Woodstock in 1969. Now he does readings on Zoom.
content: Mark Horn, a tarot card expert who uses his knowledge of kabbalah (Jewish mysticism) in his readings, has been busy lately.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Seeking Solace in Art
description: How Adam D. Weinberg, Shirin Neshat and Ariana Rockefeller are lifting spirits.
content: With the New York charity circuit on hiatus, here is how some philanthropists and society figures are spending their time and resources during the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.O. Scott
title: Sundance Diary, Part 2: The Promise of Music in a Powerful Film
description: Questlove’s documentary, “Summer of Soul,” is both a vivid history and a reminder of live performance at a difficult time.
content: A.O. Scott, our critic at large, is keeping a diary as he “attends” the virtual Sundance Film Festival, which runs through Wednesday. Read Part 1 here.
source.name: The New York Times

title: After offering vaccines to wealthy donors, a Washington hospital system apologizes.
description: A Washington hospital system apologized after The Seattle Times reported that it had offered vaccines to wealthy donors while others went without the coveted shots.
content: A Washington hospital system apologized after The Seattle Times reported that it had offered vaccines to wealthy donors while others went without the coveted shots.

description: The Madea creator and studio head talks about the history of the medical and government establishment’s exploitation of Black people.
content: Can Tyler Perry assuage distrust among Black Americans who are skeptical about the Covid-19 vaccine?
source.name: The New York Times

title: Health care unions amplify the voices of frontline workers overwhelmed by pandemic conditions.
description: The unions representing the nation’s health care workers have emerged as increasingly powerful voices during the still-raging pandemic.

author: By Amanda Rosa
title: Backlash Over Virus at SUNY College: ‘Learn From Your Fall 2020 Mistakes!’
description: The campus with the worst outbreak of any public college in New York is set to begin in-person classes on Monday. Some students, parents and faculty members weren’t happy about it.
content: When the upstate New York campus that had the worst coronavirus outbreak of any public college in the state announced it would reopen for the spring semester, a petition started in protest and accumulated more than 700 signatures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson and Ben Sisario
title: A Broadway Theater Owner Rethinks Post-Pandemic Ticket Selling
description: Jujamcyn, which operates five of the 41 Broadway houses, said that when theater returns it will use SeatGeek instead of Ticketmaster.
content: As many live performance venues rethink their operations in anticipation of a post-pandemic reopening, one of Broadway’s major theater owners has decided to overhaul its ticketing practices.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Devorah Lev-Tov
title: Can Cute Windows Resurrect a Depressed Town in Upstate New York?
description: A project in Cherry Valley, a longtime artists’ haven, is brightening storefronts and telling the world, “We’re still here!”
content: Last winter, Anne Loretto found herself gazing out at the downtown intersection where the upstate town of Cherry Valley’s lone traffic light hangs. This is the center of downtown, home of the historic village’s storefronts. The problem was, so many of them were empty — and had been for a long time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luis Ferré-Sadurní and Jesse McKinley
title: Indoor Dining Will Reopen in New York City at 25% Capacity
description: Restaurants can seat customers inside starting on Feb. 14, over a month after Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo shut down service as virus cases climbed.
content: Indoor dining will resume with limited capacity in New York City restaurants next month, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo announced on Friday, more than a month after the governor had banned it to combat a second wave of the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: The G.O.P. Is in a Doom Loop of Bizarro
description: But will it doom the rest of us, too?
content: Here’s what we know about American politics: The Republican Party is stuck, probably irreversibly, in a doom loop of bizarro. If the Trump-incited Capitol insurrection didn’t snap the party back to sanity — and it didn’t — nothing will.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Wesley Morris
title: Cicely Tyson Kept It Together So We Didn’t Fall Apart
description: A wonder of poise and punch, the actress dared to declare herself a moral progenitor, taking on roles that reflected the dignity of Black women.
content: How odd to celebrate someone for not being who we’ve been programmed to expect. But American entertainment worked hard on the mold that Cicely Tyson refused to fit. So, really, what we’ve been saluting all these decades was historic defiance. She died on Thursday, at 96, just after the release of “Just as I Am,” a juicy, honest, passionately Cicely memoir. (“Well, child, I’ll tell you: my mouth fell open like a broken pocketbook.”) And on the opening pages resides the truth about why, as a performer, she was the way she was.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives, Maria Abi-Habib and Oscar Lopez
title: Mexico’s death toll becomes the world’s third highest, surpassing India’s.
description: As of Friday, Mexico had recorded 155,145 coronavirus deaths and more than 1.8 million cases. President Andrés Manuel López Obrador has downplayed the threat of the virus.
content: Mexico’s confirmed coronavirus death toll surpassed India’s on Thursday to become the world’s third-highest, after months in which President Andrés Manuel López Obrador downplayed the virus as his government scrambled to control it.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tet Is Full of Traditions, but You Can Have It Your Way
description: Plenty of rule-bending and innovation has been brought to Vietnamese Lunar New Year feasts as the diaspora has grown.
content: Even during the lean years of the late 1970s through the mid-80s, when Vietnam’s economy was strictly controlled by the government, Nguyen Phan Que Mai’s family managed to gracefully celebrate Tet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Buckley
title: Tibetan Who Spoke Out for Language Rights Is Freed From Chinese Prison
description: Tashi Wangchuk was sentenced to five years in prison after telling The New York Times that Tibetan language education was being repressed.
content: A Tibetan businessman has been released from prison in China after completing a five-year sentence for “inciting separatism” by campaigning for Tibetan language education, including in interviews with The New York Times, his lawyer said on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Brooks
title: Children Need to Be Back in School Tomorrow
description: Teacher resistance is a disaster for the most vulnerable.
content: There’s a wave of anti-intellectualism sweeping America. There are people across the country who deny evidence, invent their own facts and live in their own fantasyland. We saw it in the Republicans who denied the reality of the Biden election victory and we see it now in the teachers unions that are shutting down schools and marring children’s lives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Craig Becker and Amy Dru Stanley
title: Amazon’s Cynical, Anti-Union Attack on Mail Voting
description: The everything store wants its workers to vote on unionization in person, in the middle of a pandemic.
content: A battle over voting by mail is again being waged in an electoral contest. But now it’s Amazon that opposes a mail-ballot election in order to thwart a unionization effort at an Alabama fulfillment center.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Bilefsky
title: A Rare Menu That Tells the Truth: The Pork? Greasy. The Beef? Meh.
description: A Montreal restaurateur’s self-lacerating style has drawn worldwide attention, perhaps striking a collective chord of humility in the pandemic.
content: MONTREAL — Feigang Fei doesn’t like to boast about the orange beef at his restaurant in downtown Montreal. As a matter of fact, he doesn’t much like it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Zimmer, Noah Weiland and Sharon LaFraniere
title: Johnson & Johnson’s Vaccine Offers Strong Protection but Fuels Concern About Variants
description: The vaccine’s efficacy rate dropped from 72 percent in the United States to just 57 percent in South Africa, where a highly contagious variant is driving most cases.
content: Johnson & Johnson, the only major drug maker developing a single-dose vaccine for Covid, announced on Friday that its shot provided strong protection against Covid-19, potentially offering another powerful tool in a desperate race against a worldwide rise in virus mutations.
source.name: The New York Times
